facts.fact: In 2023, the FBI's Internet Crime Complaint Center (IC3) received over 880,000 cybercrime complaints with potential losses exceeding $12.5 billion.
Business Email Compromise (BEC) remains one of the most financially damaging online crimes. It exploits the fact that so many of us rely on email to conduct business.

Phishing emails often create a false sense of urgency to make you act quickly without thinking. Always take a moment to verify urgent requests, especially those involving money or sensitive information.
A legitimate company will never ask for your password via email. If you receive such a request, it's almost certainly a phishing attempt.
Spear phishing attacks target specific individuals or organizations, often using personal information gathered from social media to make the scam more convincing.
Always hover over links in emails to preview the URL before clicking. Phishers often use URLs that look similar to legitimate ones, like 'paypa1.com' instead of 'paypal.com'.
Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) can prevent 99% of automated attacks, even if your password is compromised through a phishing attack.
Vishing (voice phishing) attacks increased significantly during the pandemic, with scammers exploiting the rise in remote work.
Smishing (SMS phishing) attacks often use package delivery notifications or fake bank alerts to trick users into clicking malicious links.
Grammar and spelling errors are common red flags in phishing emails, as many attacks originate from non-native English speakers.
The most common phishing lures include fake login pages, payment notifications, and security alerts.
Never enter your credentials on a website you accessed through an email link. Instead, manually type the website address in your browser.
Cybercriminals often use current events and disasters to create convincing phishing schemes, like COVID-19 relief payments or natural disaster donations.
Check the sender's email address carefully. Phishers often use addresses that look similar to legitimate ones but have slight variations.
If a deal sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Phishers often use promises of money or prizes to lure victims.
Keep your software and systems updated. Security patches often fix vulnerabilities that phishers could exploit.
Using unique passwords for each account limits the damage if one account is compromised through a phishing attack.
Phishers often create a false sense of authority by impersonating executives or IT staff. Always verify unusual requests through a different communication channel.
QR code phishing (quishing) is an emerging threat where scammers use malicious QR codes to direct victims to fake websites.
The average cost of a data breach caused by phishing was $4.91 million in 2023, significantly higher than breaches with other initial attack vectors.
Enable email authentication protocols like DMARC, SPF, and DKIM to help prevent email spoofing attacks.
AI-powered phishing attacks are becoming more sophisticated, using natural language processing to create more convincing scam messages.
Browser-based security tools can help identify known phishing websites before you enter any sensitive information.
Regular phishing awareness training can reduce an organization's susceptibility to phishing attacks by up to 75%.
Some phishers use fake browser pop-ups that claim your computer is infected to trick you into downloading malware.
The financial sector is the most targeted industry for phishing attacks, followed by SaaS and webmail providers.
Clone phishing occurs when attackers copy a legitimate email you've received and replace the links with malicious ones.
Using a password manager can help you identify fake login pages, as it won't auto-fill credentials on unknown websites.
Zero-day phishing attacks exploit newly discovered vulnerabilities before security patches are available.
Always report phishing attempts to your IT department or relevant authorities. Your report could help prevent others from falling victim.
